Is there any other logical reason the money greed and hopes that people will buy multiple items from the in game shop that the housing items for our decor is not like mogs, once you have one item you then have an infinit pieces of that one item to place? 
Imagine thinking there is scarcity in a digital product feels a bit stupid if you ask me.
Further more i Hate, and i mean that with a capital H, that when i open the catalogue in game i am displayed the shop items aswell as the items i own in alphabetical order.. i do hope there is a way to toggle that off because not only is that distracting while building but it's also very forced marketing to have the items constantly showed in your face

snippet.textDisplay:
The only criticism I have of it.
Is that decos are not unlocks like transmogs. 
I dont want to have to buy 10 shrubberies. Or chairs. Or anything.
Let us unlock the pieces and once it is unlocked place as many as we want/need. Please. Get rid of deco quantities. That's my only gripes with it.
That would make it the best housing system of any game. There is NO NEED to make it a grindfest and/or a massive gold sink. We already have plenty of gold drains mid seasons. Enough of the endless grinds.
MAKE IT ACCESSIBLE and simple as can be for everyone. Please PLEASE.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ultima Online (first MMORPG with player houses) has open world player houses that are fully customizable from the plot up.. It's a 2D game, it's old.. But for years it has been considered to be one of the best player housing systems in a MMORPG.. There's hundreds of thousands of decorative rares throughout the game that you can obtain or craft, they also hand out decorations during holidays like on Halloween, there is Christmas and Halloween events that come with different decorations each year that people will decorate their homes with.. Guilds used to band together to create player run towns.. We would build townhalls, guild houses, vineyards, inn & taverns, PVP arenas, player run auction houses.. Anything was possible.. And with the player run economy you could have a vendor at your home and it was a main source of trade in UO (no auction NPCs) it really was ahead of its time.. It was a heavily social game with a lot of great roleplaying, there was a lot of freedom since it was a sandbox, but with loads of depth.. My own house was customized to look like a tavern, and you could give your house a name on your house sign, my read "Maplehurst" and I rped a barenteder/tavernkeeper character for years and the game even allowed us to brew drinks using alchemy and distilleries and we could name the drink whatever we want with our name on the bottle..

This led to lots of scenarios and re-playability that has been lacking in WoW and it's why I have more hours logged in UO (since 1997) than I ever did with World of Warcraft.. And I hope that the player housing system of WoW changes that.. It's the main reason I never really played WoW but the player housing has me interested.. The problem that WoW has had throughout the years is that it's way too casual of a game, you hit max level and easily deplete the content until you are left doing nothing but chores and there's not much to do when you're at max level.. This is why player driven features are needed and WoW has been absent of anything player driven since it's birth, players are unable to make any large impact on the game world itself.. Until now.. Player houses are a player driven feature in every single sandbox MMORPG. Their player housing system diverts WOW from a theme park and into a "sandbox" MMO, especially with the amount of freedom and customization they seem to be willing to give players.. It is quite incredible and I am looking forward to it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ultima Online (first MMORPG with player houses) has open world player houses that are fully customizable from the plot up.. It's a 2D game, it's old.. But for years it has been considered to be one of the best player housing systems in a MMORPG.. There's hundreds of thousands of decorative rares throughout the game that you can obtain or craft, they also hand out decorations during holidays like on Halloween, there is Christmas and Halloween events that come with different decorations each year that people will decorate their homes with.. Guilds used to band together to create player run towns.. We would build townhalls, guild houses, vineyards, inn & taverns, PVP arenas, player run auction houses.. Anything was possible.. And with the player run economy you could have a vendor at your home and it was a main source of trade in UO (no auction NPCs) it really was ahead of its time.. It was a heavily social game with a lot of great roleplaying, there was a lot of freedom since it was a sandbox, but with loads of depth.. My own house was customized to look like a tavern, and you could give your house a name on your house sign, my read "Maplehurst" and I rped a barenteder/tavernkeeper character for years and the game even allowed us to brew drinks using alchemy and distilleries and we could name the drink whatever we want with our name on the bottle..

This led to lots of scenarios and re-playability that has been lacking in WoW and it's why I have more hours logged in UO (since 1997) than I ever did with World of Warcraft.. And I hope that the player housing system of WoW changes that.. It's the main reason I never really played WoW but the player housing has me interested.. The problem that WoW has had throughout the years is that it's way too casual of a game, you hit max level and easily deplete the content until you are left doing nothing but chores and there's not much to do when you're at max level.. This is why player driven features are needed and WoW has been absent of anything player driven since it's birth, players are unable to make any large impact on the game world itself.. Until now.. Player houses are a player driven feature in every single sandbox MMORPG. Their player housing system diverts WOW from a theme park and into a "sandbox" MMO, especially with the amount of freedom and customization they seem to be willing to give players.. It is quite incredible and I am looking forward to it.

snippet.textDisplay: If they have a whole team dedicated to housing and if you are having fun with it then how much more fun would it be to incorporate your own very own butler, maid, pet, spouse, girlfriend, boyfriend, friend, monster, nymph etc that's AI driven?  You can interact with it and will have a personality of it's own.  THAT'S NEXT LEVEL and would be the icing on the player gingerbread housing cake.  Player housing can only go so far and it will eventually get reparative and predictable. Think about it Blizz, you are creating a housing system and yes it looks great but why no go that extra mile as I suggested and turn that housing into a home.

snippet.textDisplay: 6:15 Could due what gw2 is going to do in the next expansion: offload some of the processes to the players local drives. In gw2 our core homestead layout will be saved server side and we'll be able to save an infinite number of other things locally. For instance they featured a locally saved loadout system, which is saved on .text files so players can easily share things, where a dev created and demo'd multiple holiday based homesteads that she could switch between by simply clicking a few buttons.
snippet.textOriginal: 6:15 Could due what gw2 is going to do in the next expansion: offload some of the processes to the players local drives. In gw2 our core homestead layout will be saved server side and we'll be able to save an infinite number of other things locally. For instance they featured a locally saved loadout system, which is saved on .text files so players can easily share things, where a dev created and demo'd multiple holiday based homesteads that she could switch between by simply clicking a few buttons.

snippet.textDisplay: I find it to be the opposite as a housing guru in 14. You'll often find the small case of gorgeous outsides and empty insides, but more often, most people just throw some stuff outside because they're severely limited on the outside decorations (small=19/med=29/large=39 if you auto-count the teleport crystal). So there's more gusto for decorating the inside cause you have much larger item limitations to push. And, the cousins that assist people with housing in 14 generally do not work well with templates on the outside, as the coordinate systems don't function well on the outside
snippet.textOriginal: I find it to be the opposite as a housing guru in 14. You'll often find the small case of gorgeous outsides and empty insides, but more often, most people just throw some stuff outside because they're severely limited on the outside decorations (small=19/med=29/large=39 if you auto-count the teleport crystal). snippet.textDisplay:
I really hope they involve professions to a decent degree. It's nice that the overall system isn't tied to any profession itself to grind up, but Construction was my favorite thing to do in OSRS. The possibilities are endless. Random things I want off the top of my head: 

- Blacksmithing: picture frames (maybe works better for Jewelcrafting idk), metal statues, weapon and armor displays  
- Tailoring: rugs/curtains
- Inscription: woodwork and paintings 
- Leatherworking+Skinning: trophy mounts, throw rugs 
- Engineering: light fixtures, or functional stuff like a refrigerator (extra bank space just for food) 
- Jewelcrafting+Mining: knickknacks, filigrees, gems displays, glasswork
- Enchanting: unseen servants (could be similar to retainers in FFXIV), animated objects
- Alchemy: ingredient jars, wall-mounted flasks, let me make lava lamps
- Herbalism: plants, flowers, foliage
- Cooking: unique homecooked meals (could be similar to how Alchemist get extra stuff from their own pots)
- Fishing: fish tanks, trophies like Leatherworking
- First Aid: medical supplies display, any number of things you'd need to portray something like a field surgeon's tent

Pandora's box indeed.
snippet.textOriginal:
I really hope they involve professions to a decent degree. It's nice that the overall system isn't tied to any profession itself to grind up, but Construction was my favorite thing to do in OSRS. The possibilities are endless. Random things I want off the top of my head: 

- Blacksmithing: picture frames (maybe works better for Jewelcrafting idk), metal statues, weapon and armor displays  
- Tailoring: rugs/curtains
- Inscription: woodwork and paintings 
- Leatherworking+Skinning: trophy mounts, throw rugs 
- Engineering: light fixtures, or functional stuff like a refrigerator (extra bank space just for food) 
- Jewelcrafting+Mining: knickknacks, filigrees, gems displays, glasswork
- Enchanting: unseen servants (could be similar to retainers in FFXIV), animated objects
- Alchemy: ingredient jars, wall-mounted flasks, let me make lava lamps
- Herbalism: plants, flowers, foliage
- Cooking: unique homecooked meals (could be similar to how Alchemist get extra stuff from their own pots)
- Fishing: fish tanks, trophies like Leatherworking
- First Aid: medical supplies display, any number of things you'd need to portray something like a field surgeon's tent

Pandora's box indeed.

snippet.textDisplay: Blizzard has long said for a couple decades that they did not want to implement player housing because they were afraid it would split the community up, cities would feel dead.  Neighborhoods partially answer this problem, however since it is instanced you will not have that giant community feel like you get when every one is in town , for instance ( waiting for the ony buff).
snippet.textOriginal: Blizzard has long said for a couple decades that they did not want to implement player housing because they were afraid it would split the community up, cities would feel dead. snippet.textDisplay: This is such a waste of time. Yet another set it and forget it piece of content. We need core gameplay loops to be more engaging. Not something to distract us from the obvious problems for a few months. It doesn't matter how good it's design is, it doesn't tie to the core game or things you do for character progression. This only lets people show off past achievements through decor. As a millennial who has been here since Vanilla. I personally don't care about your in-game flex. Your achievements don't impact my enjoyment. Frankly, I don't even play with titles on for a cleaner UI, so I don't see that. The one and only time I care about achievement is when it impacts arena or M+ recruitment.
snippet.textOriginal: This is such a waste of time. Yet another set it and forget it piece of content. We need core gameplay loops to be more engaging. Not something to distract us from the obvious problems for a few months. It doesn't matter how good it's design is, it doesn't tie to the core game or things you do for character progression. This only lets people show off past achievements through decor. As a millennial who has been here since Vanilla. I personally don't care about your in-game flex. Your achievements don't impact my enjoyment. Frankly, I don't even play with titles on for a cleaner UI, so I don't see that. The one and only time I care about achievement is when it impacts arena or M+ recruitment.

snippet.textDisplay: Nice. Very nice! But...they've had at least 15 years since community started asking for housing. WotLK had introduced phasing - total silence. WoD had garrisons and hopes got up, yet how many years has passed since then? Exodus of players to FFXIV should make Blizzard think "What they've got, that we don't?", and make them take a closer look at other games, and not be stuck in their own dream (storytelling is a lost case...). Thus I am surprised that this is still so far from being finished. By now it should be polished to perfection.../sigh

snippet.textDisplay:
Hereâ€™s my weirdly specific worry.

When you start, you do not have access to Large Square Rooms until it seems as you level up.  If you start your house and build the first room as a â€œdining roomâ€ letâ€™s say, you might spend hours and hours on it.  THEN, in a month when you level renown and you get a large square room, you canâ€™t change that room out or even move it to another spot.  You have to delete everything to get back to that room and edit it to a bigger room.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hereâ€™s my weirdly specific worry.

When you start, you do not have access to Large Square Rooms until it seems as you level up.  If you start your house and build the first room as a â€œdining roomâ€ letâ€™s say, you might spend hours and hours on it.  THEN, in a month when you level renown and you get a large square room, you canâ€™t change that room out or even move it to another spot.  You have to delete everything to get back to that room and edit it to a bigger room.

snippet.textDisplay:
Housing is all well and good, but until they address the serious issues with the development and constant push to race to the end-game, why would I come back? Give me a real reason to try again.

snippet.textDisplay: player housing is shit
snippet.textOriginal: player housing is shit

snippet.textDisplay: Should I come back to WoW for this??? It's been a solid 2 years.
snippet.textOriginal: Should I come back to WoW for this??? It's been a solid 2 years.

snippet.textDisplay: Put a cosmetic pet bed where I can place my pet, you got yourself a returning sub to the game, at least for a month or two while I fiddle around with the housing until I get bored of the rest of the content the game has to offer for the thousandth time.
snippet.textOriginal: Put a cosmetic pet bed where I can place my pet, you got yourself a returning sub to the game, at least for a month or two while I fiddle around with the housing until I get bored of the rest of the content the game has to offer for the thousandth time.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm really happy that they are using alot of influences from the Wildstar housing.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm really happy that they are using alot of influences from the Wildstar housing.

snippet.textDisplay: RIP FF13
snippet.textOriginal: RIP FF13

snippet.textDisplay: Okay so i never paid attention, but will just be able to see these houses and neighborhoods out in the wilderness or is just instanced for you or your friends and guildies?
snippet.textOriginal: Okay so i never paid attention, but will just be able to see these houses and neighborhoods out in the wilderness or is just instanced for you or your friends and guildies?

snippet.textDisplay: Can you stand on the inside and look out a window to the outside?  If yes it is housing in an instanced neighborhood, if no then it's a bedazzled bag of holding.
snippet.textOriginal: Can you stand on the inside and look out a window to the outside?  If yes it is housing in an instanced neighborhood, if no then it's a bedazzled bag of holding.

snippet.textDisplay:
I find the import sharing most interesting, I'm sure there will be a market where people make gold from building houses for players, it's a perfect way for a casual player to level against the carry/boosting market.
I hope we can get placeable decals for grass patches or dirt paths eventually.
snippet.textOriginal:
I find the import sharing most interesting, I'm sure there will be a market where people make gold from building houses for players, it's a perfect way for a casual player to level against the carry/boosting market.
I hope we can get placeable decals for grass patches or dirt paths eventually.

snippet.textDisplay: Looks incredible, hopefully in years to come they can bring forsaken housing in so I can recreate my childhood of hanging around Brill
snippet.textOriginal: Looks incredible, hopefully in years to come they can bring forsaken housing in so I can recreate my childhood of hanging around Brill

snippet.textDisplay: First and im soo excited!
snippet.textOriginal: First and im soo excited!
